data.our-history#Our History:
1998 â€“ First Online Presence For the first time, the migraine aura is published online as a scientifically grounded computer simulation â€“ making the invisible aura visible, also to others. [read more] â†’ [read less] â†‘ The first scientifically grounded simulation of the migraine aura was developed during Markus Dahlemâ€™s PhD research in theoretical physics â€” notably, without personal experience of migraines. The model is based solely on the brainâ€™s neural architecture. The animated visuals are published on the website of the Institute for Biophysics at Otto von Guericke University.
03/2000 â€“ Encouragement from a Bestselling Author and Neurologist A letter from neurologist and bestselling author Dr. Oliver Sacks becomes the spark for patient-centered science communication. [read more] â†’ [read less] â†‘ Following the publication of the simulation in a scientific journal, the work receives notable recognition: a personal letter from Oliver Sacks acknowledges its theoretical significance. His approach â€” placing the individuality of the patient at the heart of evidence-based medicine â€” becomes a guiding principle for shaping future science communication efforts: accessible, patient-centered, and rooted in the public understanding of science.
08/2000 â€“ First Public Response An article in DIE WELT makes the migraine aura simulation widely known and prompts numerous responses from patients. [read more] â†’ [read less] â†‘ Under the headline 'How ghost images arise in the brain', DIE WELT reports on the migraine aura simulation â€“ and strikes a chord. Many readers with migraine respond. For the first time, they see their subjective symptoms objectively represented â€“ visible, understandable, explainable. The simulation helps them communicate their experience â€“ with doctors, family, and friends.
11/2000 â€“ Patient Forum Goes Live With a forum, guestbook, and doctor area, one of the first interactive platforms for migraine with aura is created. [read more] â†’ [read less] â†‘ Driven by public interest in the aura simulation, an interactive online platform goes live: featuring a forum, guestbook, and a protected section for doctors. In its first year, it attracts impressive traffic and initiates connections with the German Migraine League and U.S. patient organization MAGNUM. Itâ€™s an early sign of the need for structured exchange between science, healthcare, and patients.
2003 â€“ Expansion of the Migraine Art Platform A shared vision leads to the development of one of the worldâ€™s most significant digital collections of lived aura experiences. [read more] â†’ [read less] â†‘ In 2003, the platformâ€™s scope expands through a collaboration with neurologist Dr. Klaus Podoll, who brings an extensive archive of materials developed in earlier work with Derek Robinson, a marketing execuitive at Boehringer Ingelheim, UK. Their contributions, including Robinsonâ€™s pioneering efforts dating back to 1973 to visualize the migraine experience for educational and promotional purposes, enrich the platformâ€™s mission. Over 1,000 emails are exchanged in the first year alone, reflecting the intensity and depth of the collaboration. What began as a dialogue about Alice in Wonderland Syndrome evolves into a curated, global repository of Migraine Art.
2004 â€“ Foundation and Vision for Digital Medicine Alongside the foundation, a startup idea emerges: translating migraine research into digital applications. [read more] â†’ [read less] â†‘ With a growing network, guestbook, and the Migraine Art section, the Migraine Aura Foundation is officially founded. At the same time, a complementary entrepreneurial idea is born at the Interaction Center for Entrepreneurship in Magdeburg: MoteMedi â€“ Mobile Telemedical Diagnostics. The aim is to translate neurophysiological knowledge into digital health applications. From the beginning, the initiative follows a dual path â€“ nonprofit education and science communication on the one hand, translational research and digital product development on the other.
2004 â€“ German Research Foundation Grant A digital, personalized introspection tool is funded by the DFG â€“ using early smartphones and exploring digital biomarkers. [read more] â†’ [read less] â†‘ With funding from the German Research Foundation (DFG), the platform begins developing an interactive tool that allows patients to engage with migraine aura simulations tailored to their individual brain anatomy. Using smartphones â€“ still a novelty at the time, years before the iPhone â€“ the system aimed to capture real-time brain parameters in everyday life. This early work laid the conceptual foundation for key developments in digital biomarkers and foreshadowed the vision of closed-loop, patient-responsive medicine.
2005 â€“ Media Award International nomination for the depiction of the migraine aura at the interface of science and art. [read more] â†’ [read less] â†‘ The website of the Migraine Aura Foundation is nominated for the International Media Award for Science and Art â€“ a competition by SWR, ZKM, ARTE, and SF DRS honoring outstanding projects at the intersection of science and art. The submitted representation of the migraine aura ranks among the top entries and is broadcast on public television across Europe in 2005.
2006 â€“ Bilingual Relaunch A new design, improved structure â€“ and for the first time, all content is in both German and English. [read more] â†’ [read less] â†‘ A complete website redesign introduces a modern content management system and bilingual structure. This relaunch is made possible by the media award prize money and private investments.
2009 â€“ Migraine Art Becomes a Book Thanks to the online collection, a publisher is found. [read more] â†’ [read less] â†‘ The publication of Migraine Art: The Migraine Experience from Within marks the realization of a long-standing goal. From the outset, the intention had been to publish the collection compiled by Derek Robinson and Dr. Klaus Podoll as a book â€“ but no publisher could initially be found. The materials were therefore made publicly accessible via the foundationâ€™s website, where they gained visibility and resonance. This digital detour ultimately led to the bookâ€™s release, documenting the rich diversity of subjective aura experiences.
2009 â€“ Blog on Migraine Physiology From a website section to a science blog with over 400 posts. [read more] â†’ [read less] â†‘ In line with the foundationâ€™s mission to spark discovery and translation, the science blog Graue Substanz launches on SciLogs, hosted by Spektrum der Wissenschaft. Over the years, it publishes more than 400 accessible posts exploring migraine physiology. Blogging activity slows after Markus Dahlem co-founds Newsenselab in 2014 â€” an independent company not affiliated with the foundation.
2010 â€“ Media outreach: Migraine in a TV Special Model-based migraine research reaches a wider audience through public broadcasting. [read more] â†’ [read less] â†‘ In January 2010, the science program nano (3sat) and Drehscheibe Deutschland (ZDF) air special segments offering a holistic view of migraine. A physics-based explanation of the migraine aura â€” developed in academic research by Markus Dahlem â€” is featured prominently. The foundation, committed to advancing public understanding of science, played a mediating role in bringing this complex, model-driven perspective into mainstream media, highlighting the value of theoretical frameworks in patient-centered communication.
2011 â€“ Media Outreach: Literary Recognition The foundation is featured in Siri Hustvedtâ€™s bestseller â€“ as a source of new perspectives on neurological experiences. [read more] â†’ [read less] â†‘ In her book The Shaking Woman, Siri Hustvedt describes how the aura experiences presented on the foundationâ€™s website opened new perspectives for her â€” including historical accounts like that of Carl Linnaeus seeing his doppelgÃ¤nger. Notably, the book is first published in German in 2011, underlining its resonance with a European audience.
2011 â€“ YouTube Ban of Aura Simulation The migraine aura simulation allegedly triggers migraine â€“ or is it actually therapeutic? [read more] â†’ [read less] â†‘ The video, scientifically grounded and accompanied by a warning, was viewed over 40,000 times before being abruptly taken down â€” reportedly because it might trigger migraine. A YouTube channel is, of course, not a certified medical product. But if a digital intervention is considered capable of provoking symptoms, its therapeutic potential deserves just as much scrutiny. The takedown thus became a symbolic turning point â€” the conceptual starting point for what would later evolve into digital aura resonance therapy.
2015 â€“ Media Outreach: Aura Resonance Therapy on the Radio A segment on Deutschlandfunk introduces a novel, physics-based treatment concept to a broader public. [read more] â†’ [read less] â†‘ Deutschlandfunk features Markus Dahlemâ€™s research into migraine as a physical phenomenon, highlighting the idea of interrupting the brainâ€™s traveling aura wave using LED glasses. The broadcast signals public interest in the model-driven concept, suggesting its relevance beyond academic circles. This resonance helps lay the conceptual groundwork for the later founding of Newsenselab â€” an initiative, while independent of the foundation, well aligned with the foundationâ€™s value-driven mission.
2016 â€“ GDPR-Induced Pause The website goes offline â€“ and the pause leads to a new direction. [read more] â†’ [read less] â†‘ Legal uncertainties about whether the thousands of patient reports, all documented with consent, meet the new GDPR requirements lead to the precautionary shutdown of the website in 2016. Although solutions were discussed, limited resources prevented implementation â€“ especially since efforts were already shifting toward a new development path: the concept of neuromodulatory aura resonance as a therapy attracted investor interest. With new partners, it evolved into a digital therapeutic. Ultimately, a CBT-based method was implemented as a faster solution.
2019 â€“ Loss of a Pioneer With the death of Dr. Klaus Podoll, the foundation loses a key companion. [read more] â†’ [read less] â†‘ The passing of Dr. Klaus Podoll again delays the planned website relaunch and leaves a significant void. As a long-time contributor, he played a crucial role in shaping the platformâ€™s content, network, and scientific depth.
2022 â€“ Instagram Launch Also on social media: aura knowledge becomes accessible, visual, and bilingual. [read more] â†’ [read less] â†‘ The Migraine Aura Foundation launches its presence on Instagram â€“ with content in both German and English. The goal is to present aura knowledge in an accessible, visual format to reach new audiences and present existing knowledge in a contemporary way.
2025 â€“ Website Relaunch With Aura-o-mat and the return of the blog: the platform relaunches â€“ more modern, interactive, and integrated. [read more] â†’ [read less] â†‘ The complete relaunch of the website brings not only a new design...

data:
Visual triggers for epilepsy and migraine are light stimuli that are optimally tuned to the neural wiring of the cerebral cortexâ€”and theyâ€™re no longer confined to flickering video games.
High-contrast stripe and zigzag patterns can trigger migraines. Simply put, this is due to how neurons are connected in the cerebral cortexâ€”or more precisely, the â€œfunctional architectureâ€ of the visual cortex. It consists of specialized, periodically arranged subunits that can be activated resonantly by matching spatiotemporal patterns in the visual field. This is at least a plausible hypothesis that aligns well with existing data from psychophysical experiments and mathematical modeling.
Epilepsy can also be triggered by visual stimuli. Photosensitive epilepsy is even a fairly well-known form of the condition. In this post, I wonâ€™t go into the differences between the types of visual stimuli that trigger migraine versus epilepsy. Just this much: stripes and zigzag patterns are most often cited as migraine triggers, while colored light flashesâ€”especially rapid intensity changes in redâ€”are associated with epilepsy. These patterns have been shown to evoke epileptogenic potentials in EEG recordings [1,2]. I explained in the previous post how such spatiotemporal patterns are related to migraine.
Spatiotemporal patterns? By spatial patterns, I simply mean an image. Accordingly, a spatiotemporal pattern is a sequence of imagesâ€”a short film clip. Thatâ€™s often how technical terms work: they sound more complex than they are. But I shouldnâ€™t just say: epilepsy or migraine can be triggered by a film. Because these spatiotemporal patterns are highly specific stimuli, like created through a perfect stencil.
Though, to be fair, the idea of a film isnâ€™t entirely wrong. Christian Reinboth (from the blog Frischer Wind) recently pointed out to me that epileptic seizures have been reported during a particularly color-intense scene with strobe-like flashes at the climaxâ€”the birth sceneâ€”in the new Twilight movie â€œBreaking Dawn.â€
Director Bill Condon promised to make the birth scene as graphic and intense as possible. He succeeded. I havenâ€™t seen the scene myself, but I suspect the color red played a major role.
â€œI think within the confines of a PG-13 rating, I think weâ€™ve got something thatâ€™s pretty powerful.â€ (Bill Condon, Director)
The PG-13 rating (â€œNot recommended for a younger audience but not restrictedâ€) is roughly equivalent to Germanyâ€™s FSK 12 (approved for ages 12+). Unfortunately, adults also suffer from epilepsy and migraine. (Speaking of migraineâ€”if you read the comments in The Guardian or HuffPost on the topic, youâ€™ll find references to migraine too. In fact, visual triggers are rarely exclusive to just one of these neurological conditionsâ€”and that doesnâ€™t surprise me, given the similar pathophysiology.)
The most famous epilepsy-inducing film sequence comes from the 1997 episode DennÅ Senshi Porygon (â€œCyber Soldier Porygonâ€) from PokÃ©mon, which has since been banned. More than 600 children were hospitalized after its first (and only) broadcastâ€”many of whom had never had a seizure before.
The image from the PokÃ©mon episode (left) strikingly resembles a 19th-century drawing of a visual migraine aura (right).
Are the known visual migraine and epilepsy triggers light stimuli that have been culturally refined through replication and Gestalt principlesâ€”an image-based meme, so to speakâ€”optimized for the brainâ€™s modular architecture, to maximum effect? Itâ€™s not a stretch to say that directors aim to capture the ultimate adrenaline kick. The lightning-fast patterns they use are strikingly stereotypical. In primitive form, they were already found in comicsâ€”but now theyâ€™re computer-animated and everywhere.
Even Toy Story 3 and the first 3D spectacle Avatar were suspected of triggering seizures. But 3D effects alone donâ€™t seem as critical [3] as the flashing, flickering, and zigzagging patterns projected onto cinema screensâ€”and onto our personal screens. Smartphones, laptopsâ€”realistically, weâ€™re never more than 30 cm away from at least one screen.
So itâ€™s no surprise that wherever we look, ever brighter and faster sequences of images chase our attentionâ€”and perhaps unknowingly (or maybe not?), they are converging on optimally stimulating patterns, becoming stealthy migraine and epilepsy triggers.
You could describe this evolution as sensory overload by Dawkinsian principle. Because this adaptation occurs precisely because certain visual elements are copied, varied, and selected according to a criterion: the flashier, the better. Whatâ€™s flashier than being labeled as â€œepileptogenicâ€? You canâ€™t get more extreme than that. Though maybe Iâ€™m going too far. In any case, Iâ€™m not accusing anyone of maliceâ€”nor do I want to diagnose a cultural decline.
Every era, every culture has had its visual epilepsy and migraine triggers. We have PokÃ©mon, vampire films, andâ€¦ hip-hop. More on that later.

data.improving-aura-diagnostics#Improving aur:
While migraine is typically diagnosed through clinical history and the exclusion of other serious causes, the Migraine Aura Foundation highlights the unique diagnostic challenges posed by migraine aura. No blood test, imaging, or procedure can definitively confirm migraineâ€”though such tools may help rule out other conditions. The key remains in gathering a detailed history, supported by structured screening tools.
We advocate for refining this process, especially for aura, where early and accurate recognition possible with the help of digital biomarkers could transform both diagnosis and care.
Try the Aura-o-mat Some migraines involve visual distortions before the headache. The Aura-o-mat helps you reflect on what you saw â€” or didnâ€™t.

data.from-aura-to-action#From Aura to Action: For over two decades, the Migraine Aura Foundation has explored how neurological patterns reveal themselves â€” and how they might be influenced. Our work in modeling, diagnostics, and patient reporting laid the foundation for a new frontier: digital therapeutics grounded in brain science.
data.from-research-to-real-world-use#From Res: Long before digital therapeutics became a category, one of the Migraine Aura Foundation founders explored how migraine research could inform digital care. Years later, this translational vision helped shape M-sense â€” the first DiGA-listed migraine app with ICHD-3-based diagnostics. The screenshots below showcase features that echo Migraine Aura Foundationâ€™s commitment to translating insights directly into healthcare â€” through modeling, symptom tracking, and digital interaction design.
data.innovation-in-migraine-care#Innovation i: After decades of therapeutic stagnation, migraine care is undergoing a transformation â€” from the launch of triptans in the 1990s to todayâ€™s CGRP-targeting drugs, ditans, and gepants. But innovation doesnâ€™t stop at molecules. Digital therapeutics represent a new class of interventions â€” not as stand-alone apps, but as precision tools that can complement or even modulate pharmacological treatment. At Migraine Aura Foundation, we see this as a drugâ€“device opportunity: using neurological models and patient-centered tools to design brain-based interventions that work alongside or beyond medication. Weâ€™re exploring opportunities to bring this science into clinical practice â€” in collaboration with researchers, developers, and innovators in digital and pharmaceutical care.
